text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Finnish papers this morning.
- Some 20-30 percent of the world's cosmetics industry's aromatic raw material come from Cultor's CAL plant in southern France.
- Fish fingers are children's favourite dish at schools.
- Motorsleighing hobby spreading from Lapland to central Finland.
- Interior ministry plans easier procedure for citizenship application; waiting times now approaching three years. @
- Army planning to increase sports in its training.
- Lifetime prison sentences should be implemented for paedophiles and other sex criminals, Justice Minister Kari Hakamies says.
- Metsa-Serla has in the past year sold its stake in UPM-Kymmene, Merita and Pohjola have reduced holdings, large-holdings register shows.
- Mobile phone companies are a good investment this year, says Colin Stone, manager of Fidelity 's Nordic and European smaller companies fund. @
- Mutual life-insurer Suomi's assets belong to its policy holders, who should get proper compensation if they are sold to Pohjola, says Jarmo Leppiniemi, chairman of the private investor lobby.
- Women's fear of becoming victims of violence is turning to a daily problem, a study shows.
- Finland needs more personnel to manage its relationship with NATO, says Finland's ambassador to Belgium Leif Blomqvist.
